newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean students parade coffin in Kwangju.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean students parade coffin in Kwangju.

text.p: Thousands of radical students armed with iron bars and firebombs paraded the coffin of a colleague through the streets of the South Korean city of Kwangju on Friday.

The steel coffin of student Yoo Jae-ul, who died during a protest in March, has become a rallying point for anti-government demonstrations in a city that has just completed anniversary mourning rites for the 1980 Kwangju massacre.
Students had made several earlier attempts to stage a funeral procession but were beaten back in pitched battles with riot police ringing the campus.
The coffin had been sitting on a pickup truck parked on the campus of a local university since May 16.
On Friday afternoon, it was finally trundled off the college grounds in a march by more than 4,000 students that threatened to explode into violence.
Many of the students carried boxes of molotov cocktails hung from iron bars slung across their shoulders.
Similar student funerals in the past have provoked spasms of street violence.

The truck was preceded by students beating drums and cymbals and was flanked on each side by two rows of protesters wielding metal staves and dressed identically in white t-shirts bearing the image of the student.
Scores of colourful banners fluttered overhead.
The student's distraught mother stumbled along behind the coffin, sobbing and wailing and occasionally throwing herself on the casket, which was draped in the national flag.
Initial medical reports showed the student died of a heart attack.

But his parents and radical students groups rejected a government request for an autopsy and are demanding an official apology and the right to bury Yoo in a newly-dedicated cemetery for Kwangju massacre victims.
More than 200 people died, by official count, when paratroopers stormed Kwangju in 1980 to crush a citizen's revolt against martial law. Most were students.
By Friday evening the procession was circling the main city plaza in front of the provincial government building, which was cordoned off by ranks of riot police massed behind sandbagged barricades.
The plaza was the scene of the worst of the carnage in 1980. Anniversary ceremonies over the weekend were the first to be officially-sponsored by the government.
It was not clear whether students would try to force their way into the plaza, or head towards a cemetery on the outskirts of the city.
